Bonfire Night

“Penny for the guy, Mister?”

The old, purple-nosed man looked down at the empty, rumpled tracksuit on the floor, the football masquerading as a head, and he sneered at us. “Cheeky bastards”, he said. “I’m not givin’ youse any money for that shitty effort — call that a Guy? Fuckin’ extortion is wha’ that is”.

We watched him walk off, aiming V-signs and making ‘wanker’ gestures at his back as he went, mumbling “tight arl bastard” just loudly enough for our mates to hear us, but not so loud that one of the shoppers walking past with their Tesco bags might hear us and tell our Mums.

We’d been there all morning, hanging around, trying to make money, but everyone was saying the same thing: our Guy was shit. They made a proper effort when they were our age, three hundred years ago. They at least drew a face on the ball, or they at least stuffed the clothes with old newspapers. Our Guy was shit. People were laughing at us. We needed to up our game. The Jackson brothers living next door made fifty quid each on the Saturday just gone, and they’d only been stood here for few hours. We’d been here all morning and we’d made just seven pound thirty three pence between the four of us. I couldn’t have those Jackson kids crowing at us when we traipsed past them tonight with our shitty share of seven pound jangling in our pockets. No way could I allow those ugly ginger twins’ to do better than us, especially as they were only eight-years-old, and I was ten.

“We should call it a day, I reckon”, said our kid. Dave-o, older and taller than us, agreed. I didn’t: it was only quarter past twelve. We could turn it ‘round in a few hours if we had a better guy. Our kid, starving, wanted to go back to school and get his free dinner. So did John-o. Sausages, it was, today.

“Fine, I said. “Youse fuck off back to school t’ eat your slop. I’ll be eating Maccy D’s, later”.

John-o laughed, right in my face. “Yeah? Seven quid split four ways won’t buy you a Maccy D’s”.

“I’ll be eating in Maccy D’s all week, this week”, I said.

“How?”

“I’ll get a better guy”.

Dave-o sides with John-o. “Where you gonna get a better guy from?”

I grinned at him. “Wait ’n see, Dave-o. Meet me back here at four o’clock, and I’ll buy you all Maccy D’s”.

Of course, they didn’t believe me, but I had a plan. I just needed to borrow a few things…

When the three musketeers returned at four o’clock, they were impressed. They thought my Guy looked ‘the bollocks’. I’d made forty-two pound: it was pension day, and all those arl tabbies loved my new guy. The best on-street Guy they’d ever seen. They couldn’t believe how realistic it was, told me I was amazing to create such a thing.

I hadn’t created it though. Technically, my Aunty Jean and Uncle Kevin created it. My new guy was my cousin Mark, the dirty junky who lived in the shed at Nanna’s house. After I slipped him a few of my Nanna’s sleeping pills, he obliged me by lending me himself.

I had done him up a bit, sure. I painted his face, and I’d cut some of the fur from the hood of my Nanna’s jacket to make him a goatee and beard. I dressed him in my Dad’s black funeral suit and my Ma’s white ruffled pirate shirt, dusted him with talcum powder and carted him down the street in my Nanna’s spare wheelchair to become the most lifelike Guy you’d ever seen.

It took him three weeks to remove the brilliant white gloss I’d used as base, and still to this day Mark isn’t sure how he ended up comatose on the floor of the shopping centre with a beard made from my Nanna’s coat super-glued to his face.

You won’t tell him, will you?
